name: ES6
title: A quick reference cheatsheet of what's new in JavaScript for ES2015, ES2016, ES2017, ES2018 and beyond

cards.title: Intro
cards.body: A quick reference cheatsheet of what's new in JavaScript for ES2015, ES2016, ES2017, ES2018 and beyond

cards.title: Block-scoped - Let

cards.body:
`let` is the new `var`. Constants (`const`) work just like `let`, but cannot be reassigned. See:
[Let and const](https://babeljs.io/learn-es2015/#let--const)

cards.title: Template Strings - Interpolation
cards.code: const message = `Hello ${name}`;

cards.title: Multi-line string
cards.code:
const str = `
hello
the world
`;

cards.body: Templates and multiline strings. See: [template strings](https://babeljs.io/learn-es2015/#template-strings)

cards.title: Binary and octal literals
cards.code:
let bin = 0b1010010;
let oct = 0o755;

cards.body: See: [Binary and Octal Literals](https://babeljs.io/learn-es2015/#binary-and-octal-literals)

cards.title: Exponential Operator
cards.body:
```js {1}
const byte = 2 ** 8;

cards.code: %0ASame%20as%3A%20Math.pow(2%2C%208)%0A%0A%23%23%23%20New%20library%20additions%0A%0A%23%23%23%23%20New%20string%20methods%0A%0A%60%60%60js%0A'hello'.repeat(3)%3B%0A'hello'.includes('ll')%3B%0A'hello'.startsWith('he')%3B%0A'hello'.padStart(8)%3B%20%2F%2F%20%22hello%22%0A'hello'.padEnd(8)%3B%20%2F%2F%20%22hello%22%0A'hello'.padEnd(8%2C%20'!')%3B%20%2F%2F%20hello!!!%0A'%5Cu1E9B%5Cu0323'.normalize('NFC')%3B

cards.title: New Number Methods
New Math methods
cards.code:
Math.acosh(3); // 1.762747174039086
Math.hypot(3, 4); // 5
Math.imul(Math.pow(2, 32) - 1, Math.pow(2, 32) - 2); // 2

cards.title: New Array methods

cards.body: See: [New library additions](https://babeljs.io/learn-es2015/#math--number--string--object-apis)

cards.title: kind
cards.code: class Circle extends Shape {

cards.title: Constructor
Call the superclass method

cards.body: Syntactic sugar for prototypes. See: [classes](https://babeljs.io/learn-es2015/#classes)

cards.title: Private class
cards.body: The javascript default field is public (`public`), if you need to indicate private, you can use (`#`)

cards.title: Static private class
make the commitment
Using Promises in finally

cards.code:
The handler is called when the promise is fulfilled or rejected

### Promise function

```js
Promise.all(···)
Promise.race(···)
Promise.reject(···)
Promise.resolve(···)

cards.title: Async-await

cards.code:
`async` functions are another way to use functions. See:
[Async Function](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/async_function)

## Destructuring

### Destructuring assignment

#### Arrays

```js {1}
const [first, last] = ['Nikola', 'Tesla'];

cards.title: Objects

cards.body: A default value can be assigned when destructuring an array or object

cards.title: Function parameters

cards.body: Destructuring of objects and arrays can also be done in function parameters

cards.title: Defaults

cards.code:
---

```js
greet(); // Hi Rauno!
greet({ name: 'Larry' }); // Hi Larry!

cards.title: Reassign keys

cards.body: This example assigns `x` to the value of the `left` key

cards.title: Loop

cards.body: Use the `rest(...)` operator to extract some keys individually and the rest of the keys in the object

cards.title: Object Extensions - with object extensions

cards.body:
The object spread operator allows you to build new objects from other objects. See:
[Object Spread](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Spread_operator)

cards.title: Array Expansion - with array extension

cards.body:
The spread operator allows you to build new arrays in the same way. See:
[Spread operator](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Spread_operator)

cards.title: Function parameters - Default parameters
with parameters

cards.body: Like a function, but preserves `this`. See: [Arrow functions](https://babeljs.io/learn-es2015/#arrows-and-lexical-this)

cards.title: Parameter setting default value
Used in conjunction with destructuring assignment defaults
name%20attribute
cards.code: function%20foo()%20%7B%7D%0Afoo.name%3B%20%2F%2F%20%22foo%22

cards.title: length property
cards.code:
function foo(a, b) {}
foo.length; // 2

cards.title: Shorthand Syntax
cards.code: module.exports = { hello, bye };

cards.body: same below:
See: [Object Literals Enhanced](https://babeljs.io/learn-es2015/#enhanced-object-literals)

cards.title: method

cards.body: See: [Object Literals Enhanced](https://babeljs.io/learn-es2015/#enhanced-object-literals)

cards.title: Computed property name

cards.code: %0ASee%3A%20%5BObject%20Literals%20Enhanced%5D(https%3A%2F%2Fbabeljs.io%2Flearn-es2015%2F%23enhanced-object-literals)%0A%0A%23%23%23%20Extract%20value%0A%0A%60%60%60js%7B3%2C5%7D%0Aconst%20fatherJS%20%3D%20%7B%20age%3A%2057%2C%20name%3A%20%22Zhang%20San%22%20%7D%0AObject.values(fatherJS)%0A%2F%2F%5B57%2C%20%22Zhang%20San%22%5D%0AObject.entries(fatherJS)%0A%2F%2F%5B%5B%22age%22%2C%2057%5D%2C%20%5B%22name%22%2C%20%22Zhang%20San%22%5D%5D

cards.title: Imports import

cards.body: `import` is the new `require()`. See: [Module imports](https://babeljs.io/learn-es2015/#modules)

cards.title: Exports export

cards.body: `export` is the new `module.exports`. See: [Module exports](https://babeljs.io/learn-es2015/#modules)

cards.title: `as` keyword renaming

cards.body:
function v1() { ... }
function v2() { ... }

export { v1 as default };
//Equivalent to export default v1;
[ES2020 Proposal](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-dynamic-import) introduce `import()` function

cards.title: import() allows module paths to be dynamically generated
import.meta
cards.body:
[ES2020](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-import-meta) Added a meta property `import.meta` to the `import` command,
which returns the meta information of the current module

cards.code: new URL('data.txt', import.meta.url);

cards.body:
In the Node.js environment, `import.meta.url` always returns a local path, that is, a string of the `file:URL` protocol,
such as `file:/// home/user/foo.js`

cards.title: Import Assertions - static import
cards.code:
import json from './package.json' assert { type: 'json' };
//Import all objects in the json file

cards.title: Dynamic Import
cards.code: const json = await import('./package.json', { assert: { type: 'json' } });

cards.title: Generator function

cards.body: it's complicated. See: [Generators](https://babeljs.io/learn-es2015/#generators)

cards.title: For..of + iterator

cards.body: For iterating over generators and arrays. See: [For..of iteration](https://babeljs.io/learn-es2015/#iterators--forof)

cards.title: Relationship with Iterator interface

cards.body:
The `Generator` function is assigned to the `Symbol.iterator` property, so that the `gen` object has the `Iterator`
interface, which can be traversed by the `...` operator

cards.title: Symbol.iterator property

cards.body:
`gen` is a `Generator` function, calling it will generate a traverser object `g`. Its `Symbol.iterator` property, which
is also an iterator object generation function, returns itself after execution

cards.title: see also
cards.body:
• [Learn ES2015](https://babeljs.io/docs/en/learn/)_(babeljs.io)_
• [ECMAScript 6 Features Overview](https://github.com/lukehoban/es6features#readme) _(github.com)_
